snippet: Amid disruptions from the defendants, the government’s attempt to restart its efforts to prosecute the five defendants in the Sept. 11 case got off to a slow, rocky start in a trial that could result in their executions.
abstract: Arraignment of five men accused of conspiring in the Sept 11 attacks begins amid defiance and disruptions from the defendants, all of whom defer entering a plea; men, including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, refuse to listen to an Arabic translation of the proceedings or to answer questions posed by the judge, Army Col James L Pohl.

byline.contributor: Matt Flegenheimer contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Amid disruptions from the defendants, the government’s attempt to restart its efforts to prosecute the five defendants in the Sept. 11 case got off to a slow, rocky start in a trial that could result in their executions.

headline.seo: 9/11 Defendants Face Arraignment in Military Court
headline.main: At a Hearing, 9/11 Detainees Show Defiance
headline.print_headline: At a Hearing, 9/11 Detainees Show Defiance
